IDAP of Visualizing hypercubes

WRITING.TEXT: No I didn't mean double I meant the same from chin to eyes , would be eyes to top of the head, its kinda hard to explain in text but basically eyes are always gonna come to be around the middle of the head, if you made a line horizontally in the middle of the head, eyes would be there, of course the angle of head changes that considerably, changes the angle and placement of the ear also. With the ear I usually figure it out by finding the angle of the eyebrows first, and then finding the angle from the brows to the top of the ear, and I find the bottom by lookin at what its lining up with on the face, usually is the bottom of the nose of top of lips.

dude that looks sick,anatomy seems right, but your line work can be improved for some parts, it gets real fuzzy around the head.. makes you look unsure about the size of his head, and ear might be a bit small....and for me man, the top of the head, its usually double the distance of chin to eyes. Of course, its your style an I don't see the picture so take it if can help

Yeah, I wasn't really saying that its doom and gloom. It's just that I always think about my parents and even when I feel alone from other people, they are always there, so I can't say I feel your pain, not yet, but the way you talked about being alone in the universe described exactly how I think it will to lose them. And my dad is exactly like that too, he will never say how much he cares, but I can recognize it in little things he does. It really is a good comment, sometimes we forget how much our parents really mean and sometimes its too late, reading your comment made me call them. I'm sure I'm not the only one who will take your words to heart,its easy to be pessimistic about op's situation, but you found the right and optimistic words, thank you.
I don't think anyone could have said it any better, thanks for the wisdom and the tears
Hahaha you just made me geek, this just happened as I read it
oh, yeah I feel you

Art major Here, deadlines raping my soul right now, 40 drawings due at 1 pm and here I am on Reddit....well I have 4 done so its not so bad... Reddit has been distracting as fuck but what can ya do. Semester has flown by man, kinda tired of endless work, break was just to catch up on work, redo assignments an crap. All nighters all the time make the mind numb, and I rarely procrastinate, atleast we don't have final exams Haha, just final projects...which take weeks 0_0. I'm not bitchin, I love my major, it just gets tough sometimes, I'm sure everyone is going through this feeling now that finals are here, just try an keep your heads up and punish em.

Since a lot of people were asking about the process or method, I'm doing another drawing at the moment and will show process as I draw on my blog, www.noodos.blogspot.com Thanks reddit, much love

I have this anatomy book and just drew all the bones in the body and all the muscles, legs, arms, all seperate and learned the proportions that way and when I draw people now I can see the muscles and bones. it's basically obtaining x-ray vision. I have been also drawing a lot from life, my own arm, doing legs at the moment, it helps knowing the figure, and also have a drawing class, nude models.

heres some process work for what Im working on at the moment
http://noodos.blogspot.com/
http://noodos.blogspot.com/ I just put up the first few updates check em out
Thanks, Yeah fingers, very deceiving, I did this correctly by finding the phalanx of each finger and makin simple circles for where they were, and the contour lines came in after.
Didn't see the second half of your question but I will come back to your question, drawing legs right now and will explain the process, method when finished.

the process pictures I took for this arm aren't very useful to a beginner, I'm actually about to pull an all nighter doing another drawing, of legs. I will take better process pics and explain how a drawing like this comes about, so it will be up on my blog by tomorrow.. usually spend around 10 hours on something like this. I can still give you some tips regardless, don't get caught up in details, just start out with a light pencil, I used 2H for the whole thing, any pencil will do but, you don't want dark lines til you know where everything is going to be. Start out with basic shapes representing what your drawing, and your going to build up to the details, details come last. Whatever your focal point is going to be, that is what should have the most detail and work. I am not considering shading right now, so think about line quality too, the darker the line, the more attention is brought to it, use line to lead the eye around the work. Once you have the basic shapes down, start building up the form of things, adding more shapes. It will be better if i just show you, so if you don't understand completely, just wait til I finish my current drawing.

actually yeah, that was actually what I meant by 3 months of practice. I have been studying anatomy from this book: "Artistic Anatomy" by Dr. Paul Richer and have a figure studies class twice a week where we have nude models come in. From the book I basically redrew the whole body, both bones and muscles on torso, arms, legs, everything. Now when I draw, there is little guesswork because I know how everything is supposed to look in comparison. Semesters almost over but I've learned a ton.
Yeah actually I can upload some of the process to this drawing to help, I'm not home but I will later, and here is my blog. www.Noodos.blogspot.com. and yeah I can help you out, just gimme some time.
Thank you, it's all line work, haven't really learned to model(shade) yet. Will post more when I start shading.
thanks, its my own arm, hehe, try to draw from life as much as possible, you'll learn a lot and will be able to see much more then in a photo. good luck

WRITING.TITLE: Good god! Mishima combo exhibition

WRITING.TEXT:
Alright man, I don't know what came over me to diss your work like that, but I'm gonna try an help you out a little. ok when doing faces man, starting out is fuckin hard, cuz u have no sound method to getting all the proportions right..and without proportions it doesnt matter how good everything else looks..... the painting is gonna be crap. take a look at this, just did it
http://lh4.ggpht.com/-j-vP20acGLs/TnpqqQmgZYI/AAAAAAAAAO4/uZmDUk1E7p8/IMAG0026.jpg
Ive been painting for a couple years, and have taught a few to paint also.
you know that first layer when its all wet, using gamsol or turpenoid? the thin layer..... you wanna have a good underpainting.... Try choosing a dark color and basically drawing out where the imporant parts are gonna be....you know, getting everything right, eyes in comparison to head,etc. you can start out with the basic shape of the head like i did....and then a line right down the middle of the face(between the eyes, middle of nose) and then from there you can put lines going across, for eyes, for the bottom of the nose,,,and another one for lips...and then LOOK and COMPARE where the eyes are gonna be....and then using ANGLES from the edge of the eyes....to the edge of the nose, pinpoint the nose...same for lips....I can't help you much online besides that, try an get basic shapes to fill in the face, see the drawing?? the circles in the cheeks?? helps me see how full they are and where the nose,etc would be. I'm not saying I'm such a good artist that you suck and i have to show u everything...Im just trying to provide more feedback then my last shitty comment. sorry again for being a fuckin DOUCHE.
Afo by any chance?

WRITING.TITLE: I drew a vicious bird attack

WRITING.TEXT: RABBLE RABBLE, RABBLE RABBLE? rabble

WRITING.TITLE: What's really good?

WRITING.TEXT: actually it's Dr. Paul Richer's Artistic Anatomy book, edited by Robert Hale. I don't think angles can be tweaked later...they can be erased later, but starting out, it feels as if they help put everything in the right place. its nice having reference points and then finding angles from those to pinpoint exact location of limbs, etc. I mean for the human body, it seems like a must, until I master it, maybe that's when I won't need them, I guess that's what you were referring to. Being good enough not to need them. I'm not yet.

Starting out: http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-70bI0pdu0J8/Tm1_YjjmADI/AAAAAAAAAOc/OQHWLu_6_oI/s320/321136_10150301976404001_662494000_8029015_1936787100_n.jpg
FINAL: http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-AUOzYUwsWsU/Tm1_ZiCe-LI/AAAAAAAAAOo/19AGSA72Y_E/s1600/299112_10150302136504001_662494000_8029943_1789173647_n.jpg
crit would be nice, if anyone gets the time to look at em.

WRITING.TITLE: I learned the importance of angles BEFORE you start the contour lines

Some crit would be nice, the shoulders look off because of the interference with reference points I started out with. It's just practice for a bigger piece starting tomorrow!

A father's request

WRITING.TEXT: Punjab, back to the roots, the village.
Thank you

Haha thank you, Indians aren't really into art so when I was starting out with just the outlines, my aunts were like , your ruining the wall and said they would wipe it off when I left. But when I finished they loved it and the 6th girl is the oldest and has gone away to a different village for school. I have done many self portraits and was kind of sick of seeing my face Hehe.
